thread.title: Nadjah Nicole wows crowd at Pike Creek camp-out
thread.title_full: Nadjah Nicole wows crowd at Pike Creek camp-out

title: Nadjah Nicole wows crowd at Pike Creek camp-out
text:
Nadjah Nicole wows crowd at Pike Creek camp-out Brittany Horn , The News Journal 11:08 p.m. EDT October 24, 2015 Nadjah Nicole performs for a large crowd at "Fall Asleep Under thr Stars" in Pike Creek. BRITTANY HORN/THE NEWS JOURNAL Buy Photo Barbara and Doug Strauss wait with their daughters Penelope (left) and Lilly (right) for the costume contest to begin. (Photo: BRITTANY HORN/THE NEWS JOURNAL) Buy Photo CONNECT 1 TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE 
PIKE CREEK — Nadjah Nicole may have been cold Saturday night, but temperatures weren't enough to stop her from serenading the throngs of people eager to see her perform at Carousel Park & Equestrian Center in Pike Creek. 
The 23-year-old Claymont native — who recently wowed judges on NBC reality TV show, "The Voice" — took the stage at "Fall Asleep Under the Stars" after the sun went down Saturday, performing two songs in an acoustic set. Though locals last saw her on TV Tuesday night in pre-recorded stages of the singing show, Nicole has a short stint home before heading back to Los Angeles for more filming. 
"It always feels good to just be home," she said, though Nicole hasn't been taking any time off in Delaware. In between performing other shows, she's spending extra time with her daughter and feeding her cat, she said. 
But local Delaware residents didn't mind her short performance, as many lined up for autographs and selfies long before and after her show. More than 5,700 people pre-registered for the free annual camp-out, complete with Halloween-themed festivities and costume contest, as well as food, crafts and hayrides. Many more decided upon arrival that they would stay the night, as colorful tents dotted the hills and fields inside the park. 
Sophia Hanson, general manager for the county's Department of Community Services, called the event a "huge success," adding that it's one of the only free events located in the county. The only charge for patrons were purchases made to the many food trucks set up within the camp site. 
Before Hanson corralled her own children, she paused to hug Nicole, wishing her the best of luck as she moves forward with the competition and assuring her of future success. 
"My cheeks hurt," Nicole said with a laugh. "But it doesn't feel much different yet, except when I'm online and there are people from Brazil supporting me and saying Team Nadjah to me. ... I just don't want kids to be disappointed if I don't make it too far and then they think they can't do it." 
Most kids were just excited to be in her presence — and able to run free from their parents within the park grounds. Children raced up and down the hills with hula-hoops, footballs and costume accessories, eager to get to the next activity or show off their best dance moves.
